header.title: Talmud Eser Sefirot – Histaklut Pnimit - Part 3

central_thesis: This volume provides a deep, technical exposition of the Lurianic Kabbalistic system, meticulously detailing the hierarchical structure and dynamic interplay of the Ten Sefirot (Eser Sefirot), the five spiritual configurations (Partzufim), and the Worlds (Olamot). It explains their emanation through processes involving direct light (Ohr Yashar), reflected light (Ohr Hozer), divine restriction (Tzimtzum), spiritual screens (Masach), and the purification of desire (Hizdakchut), establishing the foundational mechanics of cosmic creation and spiritual evolution after the primordial Tzimtzum.

structure_content.summary: Introduces and differentiates thirteen distinct classifications of Eser Sefirot (Ten Sefirot), laying the groundwork for understanding the various manifestations of direct light (Ohr Yashar) and returning light (Ohr Hozer), including specific groupings like NRNHY (Nefesh, Ruach, Neshama, Haya, Yechida) and SNGLH (Shoresh, Nefesh, Guf, Levush, Heichal).

Focuses on the Eser Sefirot de Ohr Hozer (Ten Sefirot of Returning Light), explaining its function as the primary vessel of reception after the Tzimtzum (restriction). It describes how Ohr Hozer clothes Ohr Yashar and details the five Behinot (aspects) of Ohr Hozer, which correspond to and manifest the NRNHY and SNGLH levels of spiritual light.

Explains the concept of Eser Sefirot of 'equal level,' where a spiritual level (e.g., Keter) containing a Zivug de Hakaa (striking union) comprises a hundred Sefirot (ten lengthwise and ten thickwise). It emphasizes the principle of spiritual non-absence, where lower Sefirot maintain their roots in upper Sefirot even after 'passing through' them.

Details the Eser Sefirot that emerge 'one above the other' due to the progressive purification (Hizdakchut) of the Masach (spiritual screen). This process creates five levels of KHB TM (Keter, Hochma, Bina, Tifferet, Malchut), each considered a single Sefira named after its highest component, contrasting them with Sefirot of equal level.

Explains the tripartite structure of a Partzuf (spiritual configuration): Rosh (Head), Toch (Interior), and Sof (End). Rosh serves as the root for Kelim (vessels), Toch comprises complete Kelim receiving Ohr Yashar (from Peh to Tabur), and Sof constitutes Ohr Hozer without Ohr Yashar. Defines Malchut de Rosh as 'Peh' and Malchut de Guf as 'Tabur'.

Expands on the Eser Sefirot de Toch, detailing the necessity of a 'second Histaklut' (reflection) for the complete formation of Kelim. It explains how the Hizdakchut of the Masach, in conjunction with the returning light (Ohr Hozer), creates distinct Kelim for different spiritual lights (Orot), culminating in five levels of KHB TM emerging one above the other in the Guf (body) of the Partzuf.

Focuses on the Eser Sefirot de Sof of a Partzuf, characterizing them as 'Ohr Nekeva' (female/receiving light) from Tabur downward. These Sefirot receive only Ohr Hozer, without Ohr Yashar, thus marking the end of the Partzuf's luminescence and its spiritual degree.

Initiates the discussion on the sequential emanation of the five Partzufim of Adam Kadmon (AK)—Galgalta, AB, SAG, MA, and BON—from one another through a chain of cause and effect. Identifies Adam Kadmon as the first Eser Sefirot post-Tzimtzum, correlating with Olam Keter (World of Keter).

Explains the specific emanation of Partzuf Galgalta de AK. It details the initial expansion of the Infinite Light (Ein Sof), the rise of Ohr Hozer, and the subsequent formation of Rosh, Toch, and Sof within Galgalta, all resulting from the Zivug de Hakaa on the Masach in Kli Malchut (vessel of Malchut).

Explains the emanation of the second Partzuf of AK, AB, at the level of Hochma. This occurs through the Hizdakchut (purification) of the Masach from Behina Dalet to Behina Gimel, leading to a new Zivug de Hakaa and the subsequent detachment and emanation of Partzuf AB from Galgalta.

Explains the emanation of the third Partzuf of AK, SAG, at the level of Bina. It outlines how further purification of the Masach from Behina Gimel to Behina Bet in the Tabur of AB de AK triggers a new Zivug, causing SAG to emerge. It clarifies Tabur's role as the emanator (Maatzil) for the subsequent Partzufim.

Explains the emanation of the fourth and fifth Partzufim of AK, MA and BON. MA emerges at the level of Zeir Anpin (ZA) following purification to Behina Aleph, and BON at the level of Malchut/Shoresh. This chapter introduces the concept of the 'breaking of the vessels' (Shevirat haKelim) and positions these Partzufim within Olam ha Nekudim and Olam Atzilut.

Elaborates on the 'Hitlabshut' (clothing/interpenetration) of Partzufim. It explains why Partzufim emanate 'one below the other' (the Tabur of the upper Partzuf becomes the Peh de Rosh of the lower Partzuf) versus the internal Sefirot emerging 'one above the other.' The process hinges on new 'Aviut' (coarseness) being acquired for the birth of each subsequent Partzuf.

Details the two Tzimtzumim (restrictions) and their effects on the Olamot (Worlds). Tzimtzum Aleph restricted only Kli Malchut. Tzimtzum Bet, occurring in Partzuf Nekudot de SAG de AK, caused Malchut to rise to Bina, creating a new Sium (end) called the 'Parsa' and dividing the Worlds into Atzilut (above Parsa) and Beria, Yetzira, Assiya (BYA) below Parsa.

Explains the Keter (Crown) and ABYA (Atzilut, Beria, Yetzira, Assiya) within the five Partzufim of Atzilut and within each individual degree. It illustrates how Olam Atzilut is internally divided into a fractal ABYA structure: Rosh as Keter, Peh to Chazeh as Atzilut, Chazeh to Tabur as Beria, and Tabur downward as Yetzira and Assiya, mirroring the larger cosmic division.

key_concepts.definition: The Ten Divine Emanations, attributes, or vessels through which the Ein Sof (Infinite) manifests and operates in creation.
Direct Light; the straight, unrestricted flow of divine emanation from the Ein Sof into the Kelim (vessels).
Returning Light; the light reflected upwards by the Masach (spiritual screen) in response to the Ohr Yashar, which then serves as the vessel of reception for the Ohr Elyon (Upper Light).
A complete spiritual configuration or 'Face,' representing a full spiritual degree with its own Rosh (Head), Toch (Interior/Body), and Sof (End), each composed of Eser Sefirot.
The primordial act of divine self-restriction or contraction, creating a vacant space for the subsequent emergence of creation. The text distinguishes between Tzimtzum Aleph and Tzimtzum Bet.
A spiritual screen or barrier within Malchut (the tenth Sefira) that limits the direct reception of Ohr Yashar based on the Aviut (desire to receive) and reflects Ohr Hozer upwards.
Spiritual coarseness or the intensity of the desire to receive light, which determines the strength of the Masach's resistance and the height to which Ohr Hozer can ascend.
Purification; the process by which the Masach reduces its Aviut (coarseness), enabling higher levels of light to be received or new Partzufim to emerge.
Striking Union; a spiritual copulation or interaction between the Ohr Elyon (Upper Light) and the Masach, which generates Ohr Hozer and determines the level of the Partzuf's emanation.
The 'Head' of a Partzuf, where the Zivug de Hakaa occurs and the Ohr Hozer acts as Shorashim (roots) for the formation of the Kelim (vessels).
The 'Interior' or 'Guf' (Body) of a Partzuf, extending from Peh (Mouth) to Tabur (Navel). This is where complete Kelim receive and clothe Ohr Yashar.
The 'End' of a Partzuf, extending from Tabur downwards. This region receives only Ohr Hozer (called Ohr Nekeva) without Ohr Yashar, marking the cessation of the Partzuf's direct luminescence.
The 'Mouth' of a Partzuf, which is the Malchut de Rosh (Malchut of the Head) and the point where the Ohr Hozer begins its descent into the Toch.
The 'Navel' of a Partzuf, which is the Malchut de Guf (Malchut of the Body) and the boundary where the Toch (receiving Ohr Yashar) ends and the Sof (receiving only Ohr Hozer) begins.

The Spiritual Worlds, specifically Adam Kadmon (AK), Atzilut, Beria, Yetzira, and Assiya (ABYA), representing descending levels of spiritual reality, each with distinct characteristics and a unique relationship to the Tzimtzum.
A spiritual barrier created by Tzimtzum Bet in the Chazeh (chest) of Partzuf Nekudot de SAG de AK, which separates Olam Atzilut above it from Olamot Beria, Yetzira, and Assiya (BYA) below it.

practical_system.description: The 'Talmud Eser Sefirot' is fundamentally a theoretical and philosophical treatise, not a manual for specific rituals or spells. However, its comprehensive elucidation of the divine system constitutes the bedrock for advanced Kabbalistic spiritual practice (Avodah). The 'practical mechanics' described are the internal, dynamic processes of the spiritual worlds themselves—the interplay of light and vessels, restriction and expansion, purification and emanation. For the practitioner, deeply understanding these intricate structures and their relationships is itself the 'operative' work. This intellectual and spiritual comprehension allows the individual soul to consciously align with the cosmic process of Tikkun (correction), transforming their own inner 'Masach' and 'Aviut' to receive and reflect divine light appropriately. The study cultivates a consciousness attuned to the energetic flow of the Sefirot and Partzufim, thereby facilitating inner spiritual development and contributing to the overall cosmic correction.
tools: Intellectual comprehension and deep study of Kabbalistic texts, especially those by the Ari and Baal HaSulam.
Conscious cultivation of the spiritual 'Masach' (screen) to regulate the reception of 'Ohr Yashar' (direct light) and generate 'Ohr Hozer' (returning light).
Self-awareness and refinement of 'Aviut' (desire to receive) to transform ego-driven reception into altruistic bestowal, mirroring the divine attributes.
rituals: Deep meditative study (Limud) of the Eser Sefirot and Partzufim, particularly their internal dynamics and relationships, often involving visualization.
Intentional prayer (Kavanot) and recitation of divine names, aligning personal consciousness with the described emanative processes.
Ethical and moral purification (Tikkun haMidot) to refine one's inner 'Aviut' (desire to receive) and strengthen the spiritual 'Masach' for altruistic reception.

relevant_quotes.text: There are thirteen kinds of Eser Sefirot before us. These kinds all bear the same names and are compatible. However, there are major differentiations among them, requiring a prior knowledge to thoroughly grasp the specifics of each and every kind.

The Eser Sefirot of Ohr Yashar, which are Dalet Behinot HB TM and their Shoresh, called Keter, have already been explained thoroughly (Part 3, Chap 1, Ohr Pnimi, item 9). These Eser Sefirot are contained in the Ohr Ein Sof itself, and there is no Hidush of Ohr in all the Olamot except from Ein Sof.
The measure of the Ohr that was suitable for clothing in Malchut had the Masach not pushed backward is called Ohr Hozer.
Partzuf means a complete degree containing three times Eser Sefirot Rosh, Toch, Sof.
Malchut de Rosh is called Peh; Malchut de Guf is called Tabur.

After that, in Partzuf Nekudot de SAG de AK, there was a second Tzimtzum, where the Malchut that ends the Kav of Ohr Ein Sof that stood at the point of Olam ha Zeh, rose to the place of Chazeh de Partzuf Nekudot de SAG de AK. It ended the Kav of Ohr Ein Sof there and half of Tifferet and NHYM from the Chazeh of the Partzuf downward remained empty, without Ohr.
In each and every Partzuf in them, the Rosh is regarded as Keter, from Peh to Chazeh as Atzilut, and from Chazeh to Tabur as Beria. Finally, from Tabur down it is regarded as Yetzira and Assiya.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is a cornerstone of Lurianic Kabbalah, offering an extraordinarily detailed and complex blueprint of divine emanation and the architecture of the spiritual worlds. Its technical explanations of concepts like Ohr Yashar, Ohr Hozer, Partzufim, Tzimtzum, Masach, and Hizdakchut provide the essential cosmological and metaphysical framework for understanding the Kabbalistic process of Tikkun (correction). For advanced practitioners and scholars of Kabbalah, this text is indispensable for comprehending the operative mechanics of spiritual reality and the path to achieving spiritual alignment. Its influence extends to various branches of Western Esotericism, particularly Hermetic Qabalah, offering a deep philosophical and structural model for magical and mystical work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of advanced students and practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah, as well as academic researchers specializing in Jewish mysticism and Western Esotericism. A significant prior understanding of fundamental Kabbalistic concepts and terminology is required due to the profound technical depth and intricate details presented.
